ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: How valuable this course is is directly related to the project on which you work. There was also more focus on writing style than content.
Excellent class. Anyone who wants to work at the intersection of Business and Environment should consider taking it. Working with the client gave me a hands-on experience on consulting.
The course lectures were very elementary and did not teach me anything. The same can be said for most guest lectures.

It completely depends on which project you have. Ours did not end up being very good. I like Maureen a lot, and she cares very much about helping out each group with its project. I just don't find her lectures very helpful or engaging, and our project ended up being pretty bad. Also, she's very set in thinking that there's only one way to write well. I disagree. Plenty of people prefer more complex sentences that capture nuance and make the words flow, jump out, provide a narrative, etc. I can write a beautiful, rich sentence that gets a low score by that silly metric. Or, I can divide it into three stilted sentences that sound like a not-particularly-bright middle schooler wrote them and get a higher score. I've never ever once run into anyone in the working world who cared about this, nor have I ever been told anything but that my writing was excellent and appropriate for the audience. I think we just have to agree to disagree.

The instructor did a good job organizing the course, but I think that the project selections could be improved. To be honest, none of the projects seemed particularly appealing, but because we are required to take a capstone course, and this was the only course that fit into my schedule, I felt a little forced to take it. I personally don't think that anyone with work experience could greatly benefit from taking the course.
The course teaches very practical skills on project management and teamwork, and Maureen is awesome.
Q10: Maureen goes an extra mile for students. She is so dedicated and considerate.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Class lectures, guest speakers, clients made this class a strong opportunity for learning
I had a great team and we worked together really well so I enjoyed doing the project. Everyone was on top of their game and willing to step in when needed.
Working with a client on a real world project
Opportunity to gain a little consulting experience for those who don't have a background in consulting

For people who are interested in environmental consulting, this course is a perfect choice. I was able to work closely with clients, understand their requirements and deliver good quality work with my team.
It is a very practical course. Gives us handon experince of working in actual business atmosphere.
Great "real world" experience and teacher guidance -- a course I will highly recommend. Group work is very well structured from the get-go and promotes effective team work throughout the semester.
In theory, the ability to work with a client.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: So far I can't see any
Some projects were really 'intense' while we ended up with something relatively simple. I'm not sure how that affected our performance in the class.
Lectures

The lectures are not very helpful, and several of the guest lecturers were boring. One that comes to mind is the former FESer who worked at YCELP. Class is also scheduled at a terrible time, so always conflicts with interesting things going on on campus, club meetings, etc.
As mentioned above, the selection of projects could be improved. However, I understand that different students would have different opinions of what is considered to be an interesting project
Overall the course is perfect. Maybe ask people pay more attention to their classmates' presentations.

More attention to team dynamics. Feedback was very badly structured - it only asked about quantity/quality of work and did not get at team dynamics. Feedback (including the suggested phrases included as an example) "crossed the net", were not very constructive and would not have been acceptable at SOM. Many clients were not good to work with.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No lab section, but meeting with the instructor. Meeting with the instructor was very helpful, and Maureen is always available to provide feedback.

There weren't any lab sections, but I think that the weekly checkup meetings could have been changed to once every two weeks (or maybe half an hour each week). They were helpful, but sometimes there's just not that much to provide a one hour update on.
Very effective. There are weekly meetings between the team and Maureen.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It was nice to get some client work on my resume.
Since I want to work in environmental consulting in the near future, this class gave me the opportunity to interact with a client, and get a sense of how consulting works
I plan to go into the business and environment space so this course was very practical.
I'm an MEM student and I'm required to take a capstone course
I am here to understand the international way of working and gain more exposure.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this class because I wanted a practical experience on consulting
I wanted some consulting experience and this course provided a good start!
Relevance to my degree and post-graduation work.
Capstone requirement
I was required to take a capstone course and this one fit into my schedule
I'm interested in environmental consulting.
To gain experience in international work culture and group dynamics

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, the knowledge and skills met my expectations. I enjoyed the experience.
Yes. I think the teamwork was a really important aspect of this class. I picked up some technical and excel skills from my team mates and learned to communicate better.
Not really

To an extent yes, but I think that the skills gained from the course would really benefit a student with no relevant work experience much more - I don't really understand why a capstone course like this one is required for students with work experience.
Yes, especially analysis of US laws.
Yes. It was an extremely useful course.
No - very few transferrable skills.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Disadvantages - different and conflicting schedules. Advantages - learning from other talented peers, and also dividing and conquering tasks

Advantages: Working in a group was an opportunity to bring my ideas, to be challenged, to understand other people's ideas. The end result of the group work was to provide the best solution to our client. You also develop your leadership skills. The evaluation form that Maureen provided was one of the best aspect of the class, as your teammates provide feedback on you. This is a strong opportunity to understand what other people think of you. This is excellent as you identify areas in which you can improve.
Our team was amazing so we each took the lead up different parts of the project and reviewed each others work.
A couple of the group members were free-riders so the work load for the course was much more than it should have been.

Team aspect is good. It's always valuable to work with different people and adjust to their personalities, abilities, etc. The class material and meetings with Maureen don't help in this respect. Group work is mostly a matter of practice and learning how you interact with others. The honest feedback portion of the class is helpful.
It was great to be able to share ideas and split up the work, but many times the work was not split up evenly and there was definitely a lot of free-riding
Great opportunity to learn from my classmates, not only their expertise, but also the way they communicate and get work done.

I learnt deeper aspects of group dynamics. Specially when the group consists of people from different countries, it brings with it a great learning experience in terms of understanding personalities and adjusting accordingly to bring in desired results.
The groupwork was the best part of the class, and it was structured and guided by the instructor in such a way that the weekly meetings were always productive.

Advantage was to gain experience serving a client with a team. Disadvantages were that the class does not facilitate the formation of teams with good synergy, and exacerbates the problem by not devoting any attention or time to team dynamics. There should be several guest lectures from Amy Wrzesniewski and/or Heidi Brooks about team dynamics in a class like this.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Please take this class if you need a hands-on experience with the real world. Be ready to be creative, and use all of your skills ( excel, word, writing, communication, leadership, etc...)
Choose your project carefully and pick a good team!
Hope you get a good client and fun project.

If I could do it again, I would have tried to join a team for the EBP clinic instead for my capstone, or done an ind. research project on a topic I was interested in (and maybe with a company I wanted to work for). In this course, you have no control over what project you end up doing, so it might turn out poorly, and there's nothing you can do about it...
Make sure you are genuinely interested in the projects that are available, and consider talking with other students to form your own team.
Building your technical skills helps you contribute more to the teamwork, like financial analysis, Excel, data analysis, writing and editing and so on.
Research, remain dedicated, develop patience to handle group members to emerge as a leader in the end.
Take the course, develop good relationships/friendships with your classmates, have a lot of fun and maintain contact with the client throughout the semester
